text: Using non-hashable Python objects as keys in dictionaries
Python doesn't allow non-hashable objects to be used as keys in other dictionaries.
As pointed out by Andrey Vlasovskikh, there is a nice workaround for the special case of using non-nested dictionaries as keys:

code: frozenset(a.items())#Can be put in the dictionary instead

text: Is there a method of using arbitrary objects as keys in dictionaries?
How would this be used as a key?
It is extremely rare that you will actually have to use something like this in your code.
If you think this is the case, consider changing your data model first.

childList.text: It is extremely rare that you will actually have to use something like this in your code. If you think this is the case, consider changing your data model first.

text: The use case is caching calls to an arbitrary keyword only function.
Each key in the dictionary is a string (the name of the argument) and the objects can be quite complicated, consisting of layered dictionaries, lists, tuples, ect.
This sub-problem has been split off from the problem here.
Solutions here deal with the case where the dictionaries is not layered.
